study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of exergames induces ultrafast neurophysiological adaptations in the prefrontal cortex of elderly individuals and improves cognition.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in Beta brainwave activity in the left prefrontal cortex of the VRG compared to the ACG, along with a slight improvement in semantic fluency. These results suggest that exergames may induce rapid prefrontal cortical adaptations and modest cognitive benefits in the elderly.
population_specificity: Institutionalized elderly individuals living in a Long-Term Care Home (LTCH).
effective_dosage: Six exercises with exergames (specific duration/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of exergames on older adults' physical activity levels and their potential benefits as an exercise tool.
results_summary: The review found that exergames significantly improved older adults' physical activity levels, balance, and cognitive function, with participants enjoying the games and prolonging engagement. Current evidence supports the potential benefits of exergames, though further research with long-term observation and multidisciplinary methods is recommended.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 55 years and older (855 participants across 25 studies).

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of an intensive exergame-based rehabilitation program on balance and lower limb function in a teenager with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found improved scores in Gross Motor Function Measure (GMFM) and Berg Balance Scale (BBS), sustained at 1-month follow-up, along with enhanced movement quality and gait kinematics closer to the 50th percentile.
population_specificity: Teenager with cerebral palsy (mixed form).
effective_dosage: 5 weekly sessions of 30 minutes for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Wii Fit exergaming on balance confidence, quality of life, and fall risk in the elderly population.
results_summary: Wii Fit exergaming significantly improved balance confidence, quality of life (mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, anxiety/depression), and reduced fall risk compared to traditional balance training. The improvements were statistically significant (p<0.05).
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 60+ years, physically independent, with no serious systemic disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exergame interventions reduce fear of falling among community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The review found that 15 out of 23 studies reported statistically significant reductions in fear of falling, with most interventions using Wii-based systems and occurring in hospitals. Study quality varied, with 10 rated as 'good.'
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining custom-made exergames with traditional exercise improves motor performance and quality of life in older adults compared to traditional exercise alone.
results_summary: The exergames group showed significant improvements in upper-body and lower-body strength, balance during the intervention, and mental well-being compared to the control group, though some gains diminished at follow-up. Both groups experienced a decrease in shoulder range of motion post-intervention.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (N=31, aged not specified).
effective_dosage: One individual exergame session and one traditional exercise session per week (exergames group); two traditional exercise sessions per week (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the VirTele program, combining virtual reality exergames and telerehabilitation, for remote upper extremity rehabilitation in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The VirTele intervention was feasible and showed clinically meaningful improvements in upper extremity motor function, quality of life, and motivation, with sustained gains during follow-up. The participant demonstrated high adherence and empowerment, though technical and organizational challenges may affect long-term use.
population_specificity: A 63-year-old male chronic stroke survivor (3 years post-stroke) with moderate upper extremity impairment.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of exergames (5 games for upper extremity), 5 times per week, plus at least one weekly videoconference session with a clinician.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential role of exergames in reducing weight-related outcomes among overweight/obese children and adolescents.
results_summary: Seven out of ten studies reported better outcomes in the exergame intervention groups, with significant differences in four studies, while three studies found better outcomes in control groups. The results suggest a possible positive effect of exergames on weight-related outcomes, but further research is needed to confirm effectiveness and optimal approaches.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese children and adolescents.
study_duration: Varies across studies (not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the ReMoVES IoT solution, including exergames, in supporting frail elderly individuals by enhancing engagement and reducing therapy abandonment.
results_summary: The study found that the ReMoVES system, incorporating exergames, was user-friendly and effectively engaged frail elderly patients, potentially reducing therapy abandonment. The system was designed for use in rehabilitation centers and homes, with a focus on preserving motor and cognitive abilities.
population_specificity: Frail elderly individuals in need of remote healthcare support.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the serious exergame X-Torp in improving neuropsychiatric symptoms, particularly apathy, in patients with neurocognitive disorders.
results_summary: The study found that X-Torp improved apathy in the intervention group between baseline and week 12, while control subjects showed a significant increase in apathy and neuropsychiatric symptoms over time. The effects were maintained at the 24-week follow-up.
population_specificity: 91 elderly subjects (mean age 81.7 years) with neurocognitive disorders (mean Mini-Mental State Examination score 18.3) across 16 centers.
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 24 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate user-centered exergames for patients with MS, assessing their usability, feasibility, and potential benefits on physical and cognitive functions.
results_summary: The study found that user-centered exergames were usable, well accepted, and enjoyable, with high scores on usability and game experience questionnaires. However, a significant decrease in perceived importance (FSS) was observed after training.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of graded exergames on motor coordination, balance, and fitness in children with Developmental Coordination Disorder (DCD) and typically developing peers.
results_summary: Both DCD and typically developing children showed significant improvements in motor coordination, balance, aerobic, and anaerobic fitness after the exergame intervention. The DCD group demonstrated larger improvements in motor coordination and balance compared to their peers, and both groups enjoyed the program despite rating it as high intensity.
population_specificity: 7 to 12-year-old children with Developmental Coordination Disorder (DCD) and typically developing (TD) peers (32 DCD and 28 TD children).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and potential functional improvements of using the PIXER exergames system for home exercise rehabilitation in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found that 70% of participants completed the 1-month intervention, with positive trends in in-game performance data and improved Stroke Impact Scale scores, though Timed Up & Go scores showed no overall improvement. Goal Attainment Scale scores were 77% at 3 months, suggesting potential functional benefits.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling stroke survivors needing in-home rehabilitation.
study_duration: 1 month with PIXER, followed by 2 months without PIXER.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of VR exergames in improving cognition and reducing depressive outcomes in older adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found moderate effects of VR exergames on overall cognitive function and memory, and a large effect on depressive outcomes in older adults. Commercial VR games showed more significant effects on depressive outcomes than VR device-based exergames, and longer intervention durations correlated with greater improvements in depressive outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults over 60 years old.
study_duration: Not specified (total intervention duration had a significant effect on depressive outcomes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chronic effects of exergames on muscle strength in humans, comparing outcomes between exergames, non-exercise controls, and usual care interventions.
results_summary: Exergames showed no significant differences in handgrip strength or knee extension MVIC compared to non-exercise controls but provided greater improvements in handgrip strength, knee flexion MVIC, and elbow extension MVIC compared to usual care interventions. Exergames combined with usual care improved handgrip strength in children with hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
population_specificity: Healthy/unhealthy middle-aged/older adults, children with hemiplegic cerebral palsy, and individuals with different health statuses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the synergistic efficacy of exergames (combining aerobic cycling and cognitive training) on cognition and aerobic fitness in older adults with subjective cognitive decline (SCD).
results_summary: The study will assess the effects of exergames on global cognition and aerobic fitness compared to cycling alone or stretching, with results pending analysis. The trial aims to provide effect-size estimates for future AD prevention research.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with subjective cognitive decline (SCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a 10-week exergame program on depressive and negative symptoms in older adults with serious mental illness (SMI).
results_summary: Participants showed statistically significant reductions in self-reported depressive symptoms and observed negative symptoms over the 10-week period, suggesting exergames can be an effective adjunct treatment for this population.
population_specificity: Older adults diagnosed with serious mental illness (SMI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of combining exergame programs with traditional tennis training on autonomic regulation, tennis technique, gross motor skills, clinical reaction time, and cognitive inhibitory control in children.
results_summary: The study found that combining exergames with regular tennis training improved autonomic regulation, certain tennis technique elements, gross motor skills, clinical reaction time, and cognitive inhibitory control at 6 months, though some tennis technique elements were negatively impacted. At 1-year follow-up, differences between groups with the same training frequency disappeared.
population_specificity: Sixty-three children randomized into four training groups.
effective_dosage: Varying frequencies (e.g., two exergame + two regular sessions/week, one exergame + one regular session/week, etc.).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of exergames training on postural balance in patients with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized clinical trial comparing exergames training to kinesiotherapy for improving postural balance, gait, cortical activation, functional independence, quality of life, and motivation in chronic stroke patients, but results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic stroke (>6 months post-stroke), aged 20-75 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and usability of a low-cost telerehabilitation system based on exergames for improving balance in stroke patients.
results_summary: The telerehabilitation group showed significant improvements in balance (Berg Balance Scale, Mini-BESTest, and Barthel scale) compared to the control group, with excellent usability scores. However, only the Berg and Barthel scale improvements were statistically higher than the control group.
population_specificity: Six participants (three men and three women) in early subacute stroke (seven weeks post-stroke).
effective_dosage: Nine sessions of 30 minutes per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of machine learning algorithms (DTW and HMM) to quantitatively assess patient performance in physiotherapy exercises using motion sensor data.
results_summary: Both DTW and HMM algorithms effectively assessed participant performance, with DTW being more sensitive to small changes and HMM providing a general overview. The scores generated allowed patients to monitor their performance and enabled physiotherapists to track progress and adjust exercises as needed.
population_specificity: 16 participants performing shoulder abduction, hip abduction, lunge, and sit-to-stand exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effectiveness of cognitive-motor dual-task and exergame interventions on cognitive, physical, and dual-task functions in healthy older adults, as well as assess feasibility, safety, adherence, transfer, and retention of benefits.
results_summary: The study found positive effects of exergames on cognitive functions in healthy older adults, but effects on physical functions were controversial, and dual-task effects were not studied. Feasibility, safety, adherence, transfer, and retention of benefits remained unclear.
population_specificity: Cognitively healthy older adults

study_goal: To systematically evaluate the efficacy of exergames in individuals with major neurocognitive disorder.
results_summary: The study found that exergames improved gait, mobility, balance, activities of daily living, cognitive function, fear of falls, quality of life, and mood in individuals with major neurocognitive disorder, with moderate to high-quality evidence supporting these benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with major neurocognitive disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of exergames on mobility and balance in older adults without neurological conditions.
results_summary: Exergames significantly improved balance and mobility in older adults, as evidenced by improvements in center of pressure sway, Berg Balance Scale, and Timed Up and Go test. The study also noted that exergames motivate patients to continue balance exercises.
population_specificity: Older adults without neurological disorders (mean age 76 ± 6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility, safety, and effectiveness of Kinect-based exergames versus conventional exercise for balance training in older adults.
results_summary: Kinect exercise showed significant improvements in all balance tests, while conventional exercise improved only some. Kinect exercise was particularly effective for functional reach enhancement compared to traditional exercise.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (N=20).
effective_dosage: 45 minutes per session, 2 times a week.

study_goal: To synthesize and critique studies examining the impact of exergames on depressive symptoms in older adults.
results_summary: Exergames improved depressive symptoms in older adults when depressive symptoms were an inclusion criterion, but results were mixed in studies without this requirement. Future research should focus on depression as a primary outcome, use control groups, larger samples, and include people with disabilities.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the relationship between exergames and physical activity, focusing on longitudinal and experimental studies from the last five years.
results_summary: The study found that exergames improved adherence to physical activity and psychological well-being, with benefits in motor skills and logical thinking. They also noted the potential for classroom integration due to accessibility and transversal content application.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on intervention programs using exergames).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exergames on physical fitness, cognitive functions, and repetitive behaviors in children and adolescents with ASD.
results_summary: The study suggests that exergames may improve physical fitness, cognitive functions, and reduce repetitive behaviors in children and adolescents with ASD, though the literature is still limited and unclear on the extent of these benefits.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of exergames for balance dysfunction in neurological conditions and identify factors influencing their effects.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a moderate pooled effect size (g = 0.43) for exergames improving balance, with higher frequency of sessions associated with larger effects. Mild to moderate adverse events were rare, and benefits could persist for at least 4 weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Adults with acquired neurological disabilities (stroke, Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis, mild cognitive impairment or early Alzheimer's disease, traumatic brain injury, and myelopathy).
effective_dosage: Higher frequency (number of sessions per week) was associated with larger effects, but specific dosage not detailed.
study_duration: Duration varied; retention effects were noted for at least 4 weeks post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of exergames versus stretching exercises on fibromyalgia symptoms, pain threshold, and physical variables in women with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The exergames group showed significant reductions in fibromyalgia symptoms (FIQ scores), improved pain thresholds (algometry), better cardiovascular adaptation (lower systolic blood pressure), reduced lower limb fatigue, and enhanced exercise capacity (step test).
population_specificity: Women with fibromyalgia (n=35, divided into control and exergames groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of exergames as a tool for reducing social isolation and anxiety disorders during the COVID-19 quarantine period.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that exergames may be an enjoyable and easy-to-use tool for addressing anxiety disorders and sedentary behavior in a home-based environment, though it does not provide specific quantitative results.
population_specificity: People experiencing social isolation and anxiety during the COVID-19 quarantine period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of 10-week Xbox Kinect training on physical fitness in healthy middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in cardiopulmonary endurance and leg muscle strength compared to the control group, with notable differences in aerobic fitness and leg muscle strength changes. The exergame program was found to be an effective alternative to conventional exercise.
population_specificity: Healthy middle-aged and older adults (average age 64.00 ± 4.44 years, 8 males and 32 females).
effective_dosage: Three times per week, 50 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of multi-exergaming versus conventional balance training in improving functional balance for stroke survivors undergoing physiotherapy.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in functional balance, with the exergaming group demonstrating particularly strong results in specific tests (FSST and 10 MWT). Exergaming also reduced center of pressure area by up to 20% and showed potential for targeting specific motor control disorders.
population_specificity: Hospital inpatients with stroke, aged 33-65.
effective_dosage: 1 week of multiple-game exergaming (single leg exercises, weight shifting, balancing, and standing up).
study_duration: 1 week (in addition to a 6-week conventional physiotherapy program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of exergames, alone or combined with protein supplementation, on body composition and musculoskeletal function in pre-frail older women.
results_summary: The study compared exergames training alone and combined with protein or isoenergetic supplementation, assessing outcomes like muscle mass, muscle architecture, and strength, but specific results for exergames' efficacy were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Pre-frail older women (mean age 71.2 ± 4.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits of exergames as a novel program delivery method for improving physical levels and life independency, particularly in elderly patients and those with chronic conditions during the pandemic.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that exergames, along with other tele-exercise programs, may help mitigate disruptions in immune function and physical decline caused by quarantine protocols, potentially improving quality of life in high-risk populations. However, no specific data on exergames' effectiveness is provided.
population_specificity: Elderly patients and individuals with underlying conditions such as obesity, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, or binge-eating problems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether combining exergame training with fish oil supplementation had different effects on neuronal system levels and behavioral measurements in older adults compared to exergame training alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining exergame training with fish oil did not lead to additional beneficial effects compared to exergame training alone. Future studies should consider design aspects like study duration and supplementation composition to better assess potential effects.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 69.4 ± 4.6 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the safety and feasibility of using virtual reality exergaming as an adjunct to traditional therapy for stroke survivors and assess its preliminary clinical efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that exergaming was safe with no serious adverse events and showed statistically meaningful improvements in activities of daily living, mobility, and physical function compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors receiving outpatient rehabilitation services.
effective_dosage: At least two extra sessions per week, averaging 44 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of exergaming interventions on physical and cognitive functions in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: Exergaming interventions led to significant improvements in physical fitness, executive function, and self-perception, as well as increased participation in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, but had minimal impact on emotional regulation and motor skill development.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of serious games (including Exergames) on verbal and nonverbal learning among older adults with cognitive impairment.
results_summary: Serious games improved verbal learning compared to no/sham interventions and were as effective as conventional exercises. They also enhanced nonverbal learning more than no/sham interventions and conventional cognitive training, though evidence quality was low.
population_specificity: Older adults with cognitive impairment, including mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of active video games (AVGs) as a complementary strategy for cardiac rehabilitation (CR) in improving physical activity and health parameters.
results_summary: AVGs showed superior or noninferior effectiveness in improving balance and were associated with light-moderate physical activity intensity. However, data on their impact on CR populations were lacking, though they appeared feasible and safe with potential cardiovascular and noncardiovascular benefits.
population_specificity: Adults and seniors, particularly those in cardiac rehabilitation settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiseizure effects of exogenous ketones and their impact on the gut microbiome and mycobiome in epileptic mice.
results_summary: Exogenous ketone administration reduced seizure counts, with subcutaneous injection being more effective than oral gavage, and induced differential shifts in the gut microbiome and mycobiome, particularly affecting bacterial and fungal communities differently in male and female mice.
population_specificity: Spontaneously epileptic Kcna1-null (KO) mice modeling human temporal lobe epilepsy.

study_goal: To determine the effects of physical training using exergames with or without protein supplementation on musculoskeletal function, nutritional status, and risk of falls in pre-frail older women.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to assess multiple outcomes, including lower limb strength, muscle architecture, body composition, and fall risk, but results are not yet available as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Pre-frail older women
effective_dosage: Exergames sessions twice a week for 50 minutes; protein supplementation 5 days a week (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the efficacy and safety of exogenous ketones, including MCTs, on cognitive function in patients with mild neurocognitive disorder (NCD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: Improvements in cognitive abilities were observed with exogenous ketones, but study heterogeneity made firm conclusions difficult. The impact of apolipoprotein E ε4 allele status on treatment efficacy remains unclear due to insufficient data.
population_specificity: Patients with mild NCD or AD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neuroprotective effects of exogenous ketone and lactate preparations in acute and chronic neurological conditions, particularly traumatic brain injury and contusion-related dementia.
results_summary: The study found that exogenous ketone and lactate preparations can rapidly induce a deep ketogenic response, making them feasible therapeutic adjuncts for neurological conditions. They may also help moderate long-term brain dysfunction and reduce risks of neurodegenerative diseases.
population_specificity: Patients with acute traumatic brain injuries and chronic neurodegenerative conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and tolerability of an exogenous medical food ketone formulation (KF) with placebo for the dietary management of Angelman syndrome (AS).
results_summary: The KF appeared safe with minor adverse events (e.g., increased cholesterol in one subject). Stool consistency improved with KF, and some neurophysiological and motor skill improvements were observed, though more data is needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-11 years with molecularly confirmed Angelman syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous ketones could effectively reduce blood glucose levels in various rodent models, both with and without pathology, and under different conditions (rested, post-exercise, acute, sub-chronic, and chronic administration).
results_summary: Exogenous ketones (KE, KS, KSMCT, KEKS, KEMCT) significantly reduced blood glucose levels in rested and post-exercise states across different rodent models and age groups, with some formulations showing sustained effects over days or weeks.
population_specificity: WAG/Rij rats (absence epilepsy model), GLUT1 deficiency syndrome mice, wild-type Sprague Dawley rats, and non-pathological animals of varying ages.
study_duration: Varied (acute: 1h, sub-chronic: 24h to 7 days, chronic: up to 10 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of fecal microbial transplant (FMT) in reducing the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD) by addressing disruptions in the gut-kidney axis.
results_summary: The abstract highlights promising results from microbiota-based interventions, including FMT, for managing CKD progression, though specific outcomes for FMT are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare published collections of traditional Chinese medicine literature for their utility in systematic searches related to traditional evidence, clinical research, and drug discovery.
results_summary: The study identified 14 collections of traditional Chinese medicine literature, highlighting variations in scope, accessibility, and bibliographic quality. It suggested a two-stage search process using large indexed compendia or electronic resources followed by cross-referencing to verified editions.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on literature collections, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) and cultured mixed microbial community (MMC) on gut microbiota composition and metabolite production in weaned pigs.
results_summary: FMT and MMC modestly altered microbial composition, reduced inter-animal variations, enriched specific bacterial genera, and increased propionate production. No differences were observed in body weight or cytokine/chemokine profiles among treatment groups.
population_specificity: Weaned pigs (n = 12/group).
effective_dosage: FMT4X and MMC4X applied four times; FMT1X administered once.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and gut microbiota changes of fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) versus pentoxifylline in severe alcohol-associated hepatitis (SAH) patients.
results_summary: FMT significantly improved 6-month survival rates (83.0% vs. 56.0%) and reduced liver-related complications (ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, infections) compared to pentoxifylline. FMT was associated with beneficial gut microbiota changes, including increased Bifidobacterium abundance.
population_specificity: Male patients with severe alcohol-associated hepatitis (SAH).
effective_dosage: 100 mL/day via nasoduodenal tube for 7 days (FMT); 400 mg/8 h for 28 days (pentoxifylline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the reduction in alcohol craving and consumption observed after fecal transplantation in humans could be transmitted through microbial transfer in mice.
results_summary: Mice colonized with post-fecal transplant stool (but not sterile supernatants) showed reduced ethanol acceptance, intake, and preference compared to pre-fecal transplant colonized mice. Microbial taxa associated with lower alcohol intake in humans were also linked to reduced alcohol consumption in mice, and differentially expressed genes related to immune response and inflammation were primarily found in the intestine.
population_specificity: Germ-free male C57BL/6 mice and human participants from a prior fecal transplant trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early-life intervention with exogenous gut microbiota from EH pigs could influence skeletal muscle development and energy metabolism in mice.
results_summary: Fecal microbiota transplantation from EH pigs to newborn mice resulted in improved skeletal muscle fiber density, weight, and gene expression related to oxidized muscle fibers, mitochondrial function, and glucose metabolism, while reducing fiber diameters. The AG mice also showed higher abundances of gut microbes linked to enhanced lipid and carbohydrate metabolism.
population_specificity: Newborn mice (later assessed at 60 days old).
effective_dosage: Fecal microbiota suspensions administered for 15 days (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fecal transplant therapy could prevent spinal cord injury-induced dysbiosis and anxiety-like behavior in rats.
results_summary: The study found that spinal cord injury caused dysbiosis and increased anxiety-like behavior, and fecal transplant therapy prevented both dysbiosis and the development of anxiety-like behavior.
population_specificity: Rats with incomplete unilateral cervical spinal cord injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the mental state and microbiota composition of fecal transplant donors influence the efficacy of FMT therapy in rats with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that fecal transplants from anxious donors increased intestinal permeability and induced anxiety-like behavior in recipients, with minor long-term inflammatory changes, but did not affect motor recovery during rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Rats with spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether abdominal fat distribution modulates the effect of exogenous ketones on glucoregulatory peptides in individuals with new-onset prediabetes after acute pancreatitis.
results_summary: Ketone supplementation increased insulin and C-peptide levels in individuals with high intra-pancreatic, skeletal muscle, and subcutaneous fat but low visceral and intra-hepatic fat. It also increased glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide in those with high fat deposition across multiple abdominal fat types, but had no effect on glucagon-like peptide-1.
population_specificity: Eighteen individuals with new-onset prediabetes following acute pancreatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fecal transplant or Bifidobacterium treatment could improve social behavior and gut microbiota balance in a rodent model of autism induced by propionic acid.
results_summary: Fecal transplant and Bifidobacterium treatment rescued attenuated social interaction in PPA-treated rats, restored fecal Clostridium spp. balance, and normalized hippocampal Bdnf expression levels.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley male rats with autism-like symptoms induced by propionic acid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fecal transplants from Zucker lean rats could alter urinary stone risk parameters by influencing gut microbiome composition and oxalate balance in germ-free mice.
results_summary: Fecal transplants significantly reduced urinary calcium (55%) and oxalate (24%), increased urinary pH (0.6 units), enhanced gastrointestinal alkali absorption (29%), and upregulated Slc26a6 transporter expression (90%) in the cecum. The Clostridiaceae family was negatively correlated with urinary oxalate levels.
population_specificity: C57BL/6NTac germ-free mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence supporting fecal microbiota transplant (FMT) as a potential therapy for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including safety and future prospects.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that FMT, commonly used for Clostridium difficile infection, may be effective for IBD, but the evidence includes mixed results from case reports, case series, and randomized controlled trials. The article also speculates on future applications but does not provide definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a defined Bacteroides-based bacteriotherapy could be a more effective and consistent alternative to fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) in a murine model of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The triple-Bacteroides combination therapy was more protective against weight loss and mortality than traditional FMT, with B. ovatus ATCC8483 showing superior efficacy in preventing weight loss, reducing inflammation, and promoting epithelial recovery. High Bacteroides abundance correlated with treatment success, but its benefit was negated in the presence of Streptococcus.
population_specificity: 8-12-week-old C57BL/6 mice with induced experimental colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the persistence of donor microbes in recipients following fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) to understand variation in microbial repopulation.
results_summary: The study identified donor microbes in recipients 3-6 months post-FMT, with some persisting up to 2 years, providing insights into the dynamics of gut microbial community reconstitution after FMT.
population_specificity: Patients with recurrent C. difficile colitis.
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 3-6 months to 2 years post-FMT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Fecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT) beyond C. difficile infections and address regulatory barriers limiting its application.
results_summary: The study highlights FMT's promising results in treating C. difficile infections and its potential for broader applications, but notes regulatory challenges and the need for reclassification of fecal material to improve accessibility and safety.
population_specificity: Patients with C. difficile infections and potential broader applications (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) in resolving severe Clostridium difficile colitis with toxic megacolon in a patient with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
results_summary: FMT administered via colonoscopy successfully resolved C. diff symptoms in the patient, though recovery was prolonged due to underlying DMD-related gastrointestinal impairment. The study highlights FMT as a viable treatment for severe C. diff infection in patients with DMD.
population_specificity: A single patient with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and fulminant C. diff colitis with toxic megacolon.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the rates of failure, relapse, and mortality associated with FMT for recurrent CDI, as well as risk factors for FMT failure.
results_summary: FMT had an overall failure rate of 12.4%, with predictors of failure including female sex, previous hospitalization, and surgery before FMT. No colectomies or CDI-related deaths were reported, but FMT failure was associated with an increased risk of death.
population_specificity: 201 patients (mean age 66.6 years, 62.2% women) with recurrent CDI.
effective_dosage: Not specified (number of FMTs varied, mean 1.29-1.92 per patient).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate fecal transplant as an effective therapy for recurrent Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) and propose a home-based delivery method.
results_summary: Fecal transplant was found to be an effective therapy for recurrent CDI, with administration methods including endoscopic procedures or tubes. Elderly individuals showed higher recurrence and mortality rates.
population_specificity: Individuals with recurrent Clostridium difficile infection, particularly elderly persons.
effective_dosage: 5 ml syringe for intrarectal infusion (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of fecal microbiota transplant (FMT) as an alternative therapy for recurrent Clostridium difficile infection (CDI).
results_summary: The study found FMT to be effective and promising for patients with multiple CDI relapses, though specific efficacy data were not detailed in the abstract. The paper also reviews CDI epidemiology, pathogenesis, and treatment.
population_specificity: A 53-year-old woman suffering from her sixth episode of CDI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence linking intestinal microbiota to human (autoimmune) disease and assess the potential of fecal transplantation (FMT) as a treatment.
results_summary: The abstract suggests FMT shows promise in curing certain disease states, though findings are based mostly on case reports. Larger randomized controlled trials are needed to confirm causality and efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human disease states, possibly including autoimmune conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of fecal transplantation for treating recurrent Clostridium difficile infection in a specific patient case.
results_summary: The study found that fecal transplantation led to a lasting remission of enterocolitis with no recurrence for 6 months and no adverse effects. The treatment was deemed safe and highly effective, though the additional benefit of Saccharomyces cerevisiae was unclear.
population_specificity: A 73-year-old woman with intractable, recurrent enterocolitis due to Clostridium difficile.
effective_dosage: Not specified (stool in liquid suspension introduced via colonoscopy).
study_duration: Single administration, with Saccharomyces cerevisiae given for four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a fennel oil-based metformin-loaded nanoemulsion hydrogel (MTF-HYD-NEG) to evaluate its anti-ageing effects on skin exposed to UV radiation and ageing.
results_summary: The study found that the MTF-HYD-NEG formulation demonstrated sustained drug release, improved skin penetration, reduced MMP-1 expression, and enhanced dermal collagen, indicating significant anti-ageing and antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: UV-B radiation-induced mice models and old mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the effects of topical and oral administration of fennel essential oil on glycemic levels and cataract prevention in diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that fennel essential oil significantly reduced glycemic levels in diabetic rats after four weeks of treatment, with no differences between topical and oral administration. Additionally, the oil showed potential in preventing cataract formation.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary encapsulated fennel seed essential oil (FEO) on performance, reproductive hormone profiles, and gene expression in laying hens.
results_summary: FEO at 350 mg/kg improved egg production, egg mass, and feed conversion ratio, enhanced reproductive hormone levels, and upregulated gene expression related to estrogen and follicle-stimulating hormone receptors.
population_specificity: Atak-S laying hens (210 hens across two trials).
effective_dosage: 175 mg/kg and 350 mg/kg of encapsulated FEO in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cytotoxic, antioxidant, and anticancer effects of copper nanoparticles (CuNPs) manufactured with fennel extract, particularly on non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cell lines.
results_summary: CuNPs demonstrated dose-dependent cytotoxicity in NSCLC cell lines (A549 and H1650), reducing cell viability and increasing LDH release. They also showed high antioxidative activity by reducing ROS levels and significantly inhibited the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, suggesting anticancer potential.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cell lines (A549 and H1650)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether fennel seeds extract (FSE) could prevent cardiac dysfunction in rats with metabolic syndrome induced by a fructose-enriched diet.
results_summary: FSE effectively alleviated fructose-induced hypertension, ECG abnormalities, cardiac hypertrophy, metabolic alterations, oxidative stress, inflammation, and histological damage in rats. The study suggests FSE may serve as a complementary supplement for preventing metabolic syndrome-related cardiac issues.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats (160-170 g) with fructose-induced metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of encapsulated fennel seed essential oil (FEO) on broiler chickens' performance, intestinal microflora, morphology, and transcriptomic profiling.
results_summary: FEO supplementation improved body weight, feed conversion ratio, intestinal morphology, and increased beneficial Lactobacillus spp. in the jejunum and ileum. Transcriptomic analysis showed significant gene expression changes, with upregulated genes linked to catalytic activity, binding, and anti-inflammatory effects (e.g., IL-10 gene). The 100 mg FEO/kg dose was most effective.
population_specificity: 400 one-day-old male Ross-308 broiler chicks.
effective_dosage: 50, 100, 200, or 400 mg encapsulated FEO/kg of diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of organic manure and lactic acid bacteria (LAB) on soil quality, growth, and yield (seed and essential oil) of fennel plants in saline calcareous soils.
results_summary: The study found that combining organic manure (farmyard or poultry) with LAB significantly improved soil quality, plant growth, nutrient uptake, and yield (seed and essential oil) of fennel under saline calcareous conditions, with some treatments increasing seed yield by up to 625% and essential oil yield by up to 335%.
population_specificity: Fennel plants (Foeniculum vulgare Mill.) grown in saline calcareous soils.
effective_dosage: Not specified (application of organic manure and LAB, but exact quantities not detailed).
study_duration: Two growing seasons (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of fennel seed powder (FSP) supplementation on intake, growth, gut health, body condition, body measurements, and economics in post-weaned male goats.
results_summary: FSP supplementation significantly improved body weight, average daily gain, dry matter intake, feed conversion ratio, feed conversion efficiency, body condition, and gut health in goats, with the 1.0% DM dosage showing the most pronounced benefits. Economic analysis also indicated higher profitability for supplemented groups.
population_specificity: Post-weaned male Barbari goats (3-4 months old).
effective_dosage: 0.5% and 1.0% of dry matter (DM) in diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a fennel-valerian extract mixture on hot flashes and sleep disorders in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that the fennel-valerian extract significantly reduced the frequency and severity of hot flashes and improved sleep quality compared to placebo after 8 weeks of intervention.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women in Iran (n=76).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the beneficial health effects of anethole (from fennel) and SDG-enriched cookies on hyperlipidemic patients, focusing on weight loss and lipid profile improvements.
results_summary: The study found significant weight loss (4.26%) and improvements in lipid profiles (reduced TC, TG, LDL; increased HDL) in the intervention group compared to placebo. Minor improvements in liver enzymes (AST, ALT, ALP) were also observed.
population_specificity: 34 hyperlipidemic patients in a university-affiliated hospital in Lahore, Pakistan.
effective_dosage: 500 mg anethole + 500 mg SDG per day, administered via cookies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial potential of fennel essential oils encapsulated in PLGA nanoparticles against Staphylococcus aureus.
results_summary: The study found that fennel essential oils encapsulated in PLGA nanoparticles had high encapsulation efficiency (66.4%) and demonstrated good drug release and minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) against S. aureus, indicating potential for antimicrobial therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fennel seed extract improves intestinal barrier function and modulates the STAT pathway in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: Fennel seed extract protected intestinal barrier function in both T84 cell monolayers and a murine colitis model, reduced STAT pathway activation, and decreased ulcer indices in mice.
population_specificity: T84 colonic cell line and dextran sodium sulfate-induced murine colitis model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of fennel mixed with coarse salt for ironing, combined with umbilical moxibustion, in improving epigastric pain and quality of life in patients with spleen-stomach vacuity cold.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly greater reductions in epigastric pain, improvements in quality of life, and higher satisfaction with the nursing care compared to the control group. The results were statistically significant (P < .05).
population_specificity: 96 patients with epigastric pain due to spleen-stomach vacuity cold (equivalent to chronic atrophic gastritis in Western medicine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the phytochemical content, antioxidant activity, and hepatoprotective effects of fennel seeds (FS) and fennel seed sprouts (FSS) in rats with CCl4-induced hepatotoxicity and oxidative stress.
results_summary: FSS showed higher phytochemical content (TPC, TF, TFL, AOA) and altered phenolic and volatile profiles compared to FS. Both FS and FSS extracts at 300 and 600 mg kg-1 significantly improved liver function markers (ALT, AST, ALP) and oxidative stress biomarkers (GSH, CAT, MDA, SOD) in a dose-dependent manner, with 600 mg kg-1 being the most effective.
population_specificity: Rats with CCl4-induced hepatotoxicity and oxidative stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of early-life supplementation of fennel seed powder (FSP) on growth performance, health, and blood biochemical attributes in preweaning dairy calves.
results_summary: FSP supplementation improved average daily gain, body weight gain, skeletal growth, and feed efficiency compared to controls. It also reduced rectal temperature, diarrhea duration, and bovine respiratory disease (BRD) incidence, indicating beneficial effects on calf health and growth.
population_specificity: Preweaning Holstein female dairy calves (n = 57; 1 day of age).
effective_dosage: 3 g/day of FSP added to liquid feed.
study_duration: First month of age (until weaning on day 51).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Foeniculum vulgar (fennel) extracts on body weight, lipid profile, and leptin in mice.
results_summary: Fennel extract increased leptin receptor protein expression, significantly improved lipid profiles (reduced cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL; increased HDL), but did not significantly alter serum leptin levels.
population_specificity: Adult male BALB/c mice (n=35).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how gibberellic acid (GA3) modifies the physiological role of polyamines in fennel seedlings under salinity stress (NaCl).
results_summary: Salinity stress restricted germination, growth, and mineral nutrition in fennel seedlings, while GA3 seed priming partially mitigated these effects by reducing polyamine levels and altering gene expression related to polyamine metabolism.
population_specificity: Fennel seedlings (reserve tissues and embryonic axes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey beverages enriched with FOS and XOS could effectively carry and protect bioactive compounds from Foeniculum vulgare (fennel) extract under thermosonication processing.
results_summary: The study found that whey beverages enriched with FOS and XOS effectively protected the lipophilic bioactive compounds of fennel, maintaining antioxidant capacity despite thermosonication. Thermosonication reduced kinetic stability but did not significantly alter color or total phenolic content.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or model system study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-Porphyromonas gingivalis activity of Foeniculum vulgare (fennel) and its potential mechanisms of action, including bacteriolysis and gingipain inhibition.
results_summary: The study found that n-hexane-extracted fennel (HEF) exhibited rapid lethal action against P. gingivalis, induced bacteriolysis, and inhibited gingipains, leading to reduced epithelial cell rounding and detachment. Petroselinic acid was identified as a major bactericidal and gingipain-inhibitory component of HEF.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using bacterial cultures and oral epithelial cells).
effective_dosage: 8 μg/mL (low concentration) and 64 μg/mL (high concentration) of HEF.
study_duration: Not specified (likely short-term in vitro exposure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of fennel seed powder on DLK1 gene expression in testis, liver, and humeral muscle tissues, as well as its impact on blood testosterone and liver enzymes in growing lambs.
results_summary: Fennel seed powder increased DLK1 expression in liver and humeral muscle tissues, with the highest effect in muscle, and raised blood testosterone levels while reducing liver enzyme concentrations (SGOT and SGPT).
population_specificity: 30 male Kermani sheep (growing lambs)
effective_dosage: 10 g/kg and 20 g/kg of dry matter (DM) fennel seed powder

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the larvicidal and adulticidal activity of fennel oil and its nanostructured lipid carrier (NLC) against Culex pipiens mosquitoes in both laboratory and field conditions, while assessing effects on non-target organisms.
results_summary: Fennel oil and its NLC formulation demonstrated high efficacy, with NLC-F achieving 100% mortality (LC50 = 251.71 ppm) in larvae and adults, and field trials showing 97.4% larval reduction. The nanoformulation outperformed pure fennel oil in both larvicidal and adulticidal effects, with persistence lasting up to 8 days.
population_specificity: Culex pipiens mosquitoes and non-target organisms (Gambusia affinis, Sphaerodema urinator, Cybister tripunctatus).
effective_dosage: 2000 ppm for 24 h (laboratory), LC95 X2 for 15 min (field).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if fennel essential oil could serve as a natural alternative to gentamycin by enhancing apoptosis genes, antioxidant enzymes, meat quality, and growth performance in weaned rabbits.
results_summary: Fennel oil improved body weight, average daily gain, villus length, and antioxidant enzyme expression while reducing cholesterol, triglycerides, and oxidative stress markers. It also enhanced meat quality by lowering aerobic plate counts and improving color.
population_specificity: Weaned Moshtohor male rabbits aged four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-Trypanosoma cruzi activity of extracts from sea fennel (Crithmum maritimum) against Chagas disease.
results_summary: The sea fennel flower decoction showed significant anti-trypanosomal activity with no host cell toxicity (EC50 = 17.7 µg/mL). Fractionation identified falcarindiol as the likely active compound, which demonstrated high selectivity (EC50 = 0.47 μg/mL, selectivity index = 59.6).
population_specificity: In vitro study using intracellular amastigotes of two T. cruzi strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the ability of Streptomyces albidoflavus CARA17 to inhibit fungal soil-borne pathogens in fennel crops and evaluate its potential as a biocontrol agent and plant growth promoter.
results_summary: The CARA17 strain effectively inhibited fungal pathogens in vitro, with S. sclerotiorum being the most controlled. In vivo, CARA17 protected fennel seedlings and promoted plant growth, demonstrating potential as a biocontrol agent.
population_specificity: Fennel plants (horticultural crop)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fennel volatile oil on human neutrophil activation and its potential for treating neutrophilic inflammatory diseases.
results_summary: Fennel volatile oil significantly suppressed human neutrophil activation, including respiratory burst and degranulation, and inhibited phosphorylation of mitogen-activated protein kinases. The major component identified was estragole.
population_specificity: Human neutrophils (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of fennel (Foeniculum vulgare Miller) for managing menopausal women's health.
results_summary: The meta-analysis favored fennel for improving menopausal symptoms, but other studies did not show benefits for sexual function, quality of life, or psychological health. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Fennel (Foeniculum vulgare) in reducing pain from primary dysmenorrhea compared to placebo and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like mefenamic acid.
results_summary: Fennel significantly reduced dysmenorrhea pain compared to placebo, with no significant difference in effectiveness compared to mefenamic acid. The meta-analysis included multiple trials with low heterogeneity, supporting consistent results.
population_specificity: Women suffering from primary dysmenorrhea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of microwave-assisted ionic liquids treatment followed by hydro-distillation (MILT-HD) on the extraction efficiency of essential oil from Fennel and explore the mechanism of ionic liquids (ILs).
results_summary: The study found that MILT-HD significantly enhanced the extraction efficiency of essential oil with low energy demands. ILs improved extraction by forming non-covalent bonds with cellulose, disrupting its hydrogen bond structure and making essential oils more accessible.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or plant-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of fennel consumption on ovarian follicle development, serum AMH levels, and AMH expression in female mice offspring.
results_summary: Fennel consumption increased the number of growing follicles, serum AMH levels, and AMH expression in female mice offspring, while flaxseed had a negative effect. The combination of fennel and flaxseed also showed positive effects on AMH expression.
population_specificity: First-generation female mice pups from NMRI mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of fennel extract on reducing acrylamide content in French fries and compare its efficacy between air frying and deep frying techniques.
results_summary: Fennel extract reduced acrylamide content by 73.36% in air-fried fries and 29.15% in deep-fried fries, demonstrating high scavenging activity (89.11%) and moderate total phenolic content (117.79 GAE).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food-based study, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether methanolic extract of Fennel (Foeniculum vulgare) seeds could accelerate functional recovery following sciatic nerve injury in mice.
results_summary: The study found that Fennel extract significantly improved sensorimotor function recovery, grip strength, and muscle mass in treated mice compared to controls. Morphometric analysis also showed noticeable improvement in muscle fiber diameter in the treated group.
population_specificity: Adult healthy albino mice (BALB/C), 8-10 weeks old.
study_duration: From the day of nerve crush until the end of the study (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary fennel seed powder supplementation on feed intake, nutrient metabolism, intestinal morphology, and carcass traits in Cobb broilers.
results_summary: Moderate fennel supplementation (0.30%) improved carcass performance (e.g., breast muscle percentage) and intestinal morphology (e.g., villi height) in broilers, while no significant differences were observed in growth performance or nutrient utilization across most groups.
population_specificity: 1-day-old Cobb broiler chicks
effective_dosage: 0.15%, 0.30%, and 0.45% fennel seed powder in basal diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the amino acid sequence, 3D structure, lipid-binding properties, and antiproliferative activity of nsLTP1 from fennel seeds.
results_summary: The study identified fennel nsLTP1 as a 91-amino acid protein with lipid-binding efficiency (linoleic acid > linolenic acid > stearic acid > palmitic acid) and demonstrated its antiproliferative effect on MCF-7 human breast cancer cells with an IC50 of 6.98 µM after 48 hours.
population_specificity: In vitro study using MCF-7 human breast cancer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of adding fennel (among other herbal plants) to dairy cow rations on nutrient digestibility, milk production, and blood constituents.
results_summary: Fennel supplementation significantly increased actual milk yield, 4% fat-corrected milk, and fat content. No negative impact on animal health was observed, with blood parameters remaining within normal ranges.
population_specificity: Thirteen Holstein Friesian cows in their 3rd and 5th lactation seasons.
effective_dosage: 0.7% of total dry matter of rations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of fennel for reducing pain in primary dysmenorrhea compared to conventional drug therapies and placebo.
results_summary: Fennel was found to be as effective as conventional drug therapies in alleviating pain and showed favorable effects compared to placebo. Adverse events were minor and rarely reported, but the risk of bias was moderate, and potential publication bias was noted.
population_specificity: Individuals with primary dysmenorrhea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a hypocaloric high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet supplemented with fennel improved anthropometric and androgen indices in overweight/obese women with PCOS.
results_summary: The study found no significant additional improvements in anthropometric and androgen indices from combining a hypocaloric high-protein diet with fennel supplementation compared to groups without fennel. A significant interaction between the high-protein diet and fennel was noted for weight change.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), mean age 28.54 years, mean BMI 32.24 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Fennel seed powder on menopausal symptoms, sexual desire, and serum estradiol levels in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Fennel seed powder significantly reduced menopausal symptoms but did not significantly enhance sexual desire or estradiol levels compared to the control group. The decrease in estradiol levels was less pronounced in the Fennel group, though the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 45-60 years referred to a gynecology clinic in Yasuj, Iran.
effective_dosage: 2 grams of Fennel seed powder daily (divided into four capsules).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fennel seed extract encapsulated in chitosan-tripolyphosphate nanoparticles (FEC@NBC) in regulating hormonal, glucose, and lipid profiles in rats with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: FEC@NBC administration significantly improved hormonal balance, glucose metabolism, and lipid profiles in PCOS-induced rats, outperforming the effects of fennel seed extract alone, likely due to enhanced targeted delivery and stability of phytomolecules.
population_specificity: Female rats with estradiol valerate-induced PCOS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of Fennel essential oil (FEO) against chlorpyrifos-induced toxicity in carp.
results_summary: FEO significantly improved most toxicity markers (Hb, NBT, TI, MDA, GSH, CAT, GPx) in CPF-exposed carp, except for AChE activity, which remained inhibited.
population_specificity: Carp (Cyprinus carpio)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Foeniculum vulgare Mill. (Fennel) seed extract could reduce knee pain in women with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in pain, disability, and total WOMAC and VAS scores in the fennel group compared to placebo. Stiffness improved significantly in the fennel group but not in the placebo group, and the effect size was greater for fennel.
population_specificity: Women with knee osteoarthritis (n=66).
effective_dosage: 200 mg dried fennel extract (from 7 g seeds) per capsule, 4 capsules daily (800 mg total daily dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether heated fennel therapy accelerates the recovery of gastrointestinal function after complex abdominal surgery.
results_summary: Heated fennel therapy significantly reduced the time to first flatus and defecation, fasting time, and abdominal distension compared to the control group. It also improved serum albumin levels at postoperative day 9 but had no significant effect on inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: 381 patients with hepatobiliary, pancreatic, and gastric tumors undergoing complex abdominal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of fennel in reducing pain intensity and duration in patients with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: Fennel significantly reduced pain intensity compared to placebo (WMD = 0.528, 95% CI = 0.119-6.829), though the effect size was smaller than cinnamon or ginger. The study concluded that fennel, along with cinnamon and ginger, effectively reduced pain intensity in primary dysmenorrhea.
population_specificity: 647 patients with primary dysmenorrhea across nine studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of fennel extract in reducing bowel damage, oxidative stress, and inflammation in a rat model of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC).
results_summary: Fennel extract significantly reduced bowel damage, apoptosis, oxidative stress, and inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6) while increasing antioxidant levels in NEC-induced rats. It also decreased protein, DNA damage, and lipid peroxidation compared to the untreated NEC group.
population_specificity: Rat pups in an experimental NEC model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of fennel methanol extract and its major component trans-anethole on spatial learning, memory, anxiety, and depression in socially isolated male rats.
results_summary: Fennel and trans-anethole improved impaired learning and memory, reduced anxiety-like behavior, and decreased depressive symptoms in isolated rats, effectively reversing stress-induced neurological changes.
population_specificity: Male rats exposed to social isolation stress.
effective_dosage: Fennel extract (150 mg/kg) and trans-anethole (80 mg/kg), administered via gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the antifungal potential of fennel essential oil against Candida spp.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that fennel essential oil was effective against Candida spp., as evidenced by Agar Disk Diffusion and Minimum Inhibitory Concentration tests, supporting its use as a natural alternative treatment.
population_specificity: Candida spp. (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the microbiological quality of chicken thighs treated with fennel essential oil and stored under vacuum packaging.
results_summary: The study found that fennel essential oil combined with vacuum packaging significantly reduced total viable bacterial counts compared to untreated controls. Bacterial species were identified, with 15 genera and 46 species isolated from the samples.
population_specificity: Chicken thighs (food product, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if fennel seed powder (FSP) could enhance productive performance, carcass traits, meat quality, and production efficiency in broiler chickens under thermoneutral and chronic heat stress conditions.
results_summary: Dietary FSP (1.6% and 3.2%) improved growth rate, breast meat redness, and reduced muscle temperature in broilers under chronic heat stress. The 3.2% FSP dosage was particularly effective in enhancing heat stress tolerance.
population_specificity: One-day-old Ross-308 broiler chickens raised under thermoneutral (23 ± 2 °C) or chronic heat stress (32 ± 2 °C) conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether crude Foeniculum vulgare mill seeds could accelerate functional recovery after peripheral nerve injury in mice.
results_summary: The study found that oral administration of Fennel significantly accelerated sensory and motor function recovery and increased total antioxidant capacity in mice with sciatic nerve injury.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice (10-12 weeks old, 32-34 g weight)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer effects of combined fennel and clove oil treatment on Caco-2 cells and assess its safety on normal human lymphocytes.
results_summary: The study found that a mixture of fennel and clove oils induced cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in Caco-2 cells, with selective cytotoxicity and minimal toxicity on normal human lymphocytes. The combination showed synergistic effects, with an IC50 of 73 µg/mL for the oil mixture.
population_specificity: Caco-2 cells (human colorectal adenocarcinoma cells) and normal human lymphocytes (NHL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of fennel seed infusion plus dry cupping versus Metformin in managing oligomenorrhoea in women with PCOS.
results_summary: The study found that fennel seed infusion plus dry cupping significantly reduced the days between menstrual periods and decreased pain severity compared to Metformin, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: 61 female patients with oligomenorrhoea (mean age ~26-29 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of fennel (Foeniculum vulgare) on rumen fermentation parameters, including digestibility, gas production, and metabolic energy, in an in vitro rumen model.
results_summary: Fennel, especially at higher supplementation levels (up to 7% of total DM), significantly improved dry matter and organic matter digestibility, increased metabolic energy, and influenced volatile fatty acids and ammonia levels compared to the control. Total gas production was notably higher at the 7% level, though less pronounced than with Melissa.
population_specificity: In vitro rumen model (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the biological activities of fenchone, a component of fennel essential oil, using structural similarity searching and experimental validation.
results_summary: Fenchone demonstrated antioxidant activity (IC50: 3.32±0.008mM), antimicrobial activity (MIC: 0.49mM), strong antifungal activity, protection against H2O2-induced cytotoxicity in yeast cells, and cytotoxicity to cancerous Hela cells (IC50: 12.63±0.12 μM). It also reduced the activity of antioxidant enzymes like glutathione-S-transferase, catalase, and lipid peroxidase.
population_specificity: In vitro (yeast and Hela cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the soporific effect of fennel on sleep quality in menopausal women using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI).
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in most PSQI components between the fennel and control groups, except for a borderline effect on sleep duration. Fennel showed a slight but non-significant effect on sleep quality.
population_specificity: 50 menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits, safety, and efficacy of fennel volatile oils (VOs) in both original and nano-forms for treating dyslipidemia and related oxidative stress and inflammation in rats.
results_summary: Fennel VOs improved dyslipidemia, oxidative stress, inflammation, and liver function, with nano-form showing better anti-inflammatory effects. The treatments were safe for kidneys and blood sugar.
population_specificity: Dyslipidemic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory effects of trans-anethole, the main constituent of fennel, in mice with acute lung injury (ALI) induced by LPS.
results_summary: Trans-anethole reduced LPS-induced histopathological changes, decreased inflammatory cells, lowered IL-17 mRNA expression, increased IL-10 mRNA expression, and modulated Th17/Treg cell balance, suggesting anti-inflammatory potential.
population_specificity: LPS-induced ALI-bearing mice
effective_dosage: 36.4, 72.8, or 145.6 mg/kg of trans-anethole, administered once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a combination of turmeric and essential fennel oil (Enterofytol®) in improving symptoms and quality of life in IBS patients.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in IBS severity and improvements in quality of life across all IBS subtypes, with the most pronounced effects in diarrhea-predominant IBS patients. The treatment was effective regardless of age, sex, or initial symptom severity.
population_specificity: 211 IBS patients (14% IBS-D, 24% IBS-C, 62% IBS-M) enrolled by general practitioners.
effective_dosage: Two capsules twice daily for one month, followed by two capsules once daily for another month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of oral fennel on menopausal symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Both fennel and placebo groups showed significant improvements in various menopausal symptoms, but no significant differences were found between the groups except for coughing and sneezing when urinating. The study concluded that the lack of significant effect may be due to a high placebo response.
population_specificity: 50 postmenopausal women in Mashhad, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Fennel (Foeniculum vulgare Mill.) on lipid profiles in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in triglyceride, total cholesterol, LDL-C, or HDL-C levels between the fennel and placebo groups, except for a borderline improvement in HDL-C in the fennel group. The fennel group showed very slight positive changes in LDL-C, triglyceride, and HDL-C, but these were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n=60)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of fennel vaginal cream on sexual function in postmenopausal women with sexual dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that fennel vaginal cream significantly improved all areas of sexual function (arousal, lubrication, orgasm, satisfaction, and pain) compared to placebo, with a notable increase in the total FSFI score (p<0.001). The improvements in the fennel group were more pronounced than in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with sexual dysfunction.
effective_dosage: 5 grams of fennel vaginal cream applied nightly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of fennel on mouse ovaries against the destructive effects of cyclophosphamide (CP).
results_summary: Fennel extract increased ovary weight, volume, and diameter (WVD) and improved serum levels of oestrogen and progesterone in CP-treated mice, counteracting CP's negative effects on ovarian follicles.
population_specificity: Adult female NMARI mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of fennel on body composition in menopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of fennel on body weight, BMI, waist and hip circumferences, or fat distribution compared to placebo. Menopausal women in the fennel group experienced a slight, non-significant increase in body weight and fat distribution.
population_specificity: 47 overweight or obese menopausal women (22 in the fennel group, 25 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of fennel on bone density in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in bone mineral density (BMD) or bone mineral content (BMC) between the fennel and placebo groups across multiple skeletal sites. The results did not support fennel's efficacy in improving bone density in this population.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n=60)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Fennel on anxiety and depression symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant decrease in anxiety and depression scores overall, but patients with depression or anxiety disorders showed borderline or significant improvement. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of fennel oil against Sodium-Valproic (SVP)-induced liver and kidney toxicity in albino rats.
results_summary: Fennel oil treatment improved histopathological changes in liver and kidney tissues and normalized biochemical markers (AST, ALT, ALP, bilirubin, creatinine, urea-nitrogen, and total protein) altered by SVP toxicity. The study suggests fennel oil has antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and protective pharmacological properties.
population_specificity: Male albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of fennel in reducing menopausal symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The treatment group showed a significant decrease in menopausal symptoms compared to the placebo group, with effects persisting two weeks post-intervention. Statistical analysis confirmed significant differences between groups at all follow-up points.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 45 to 60 years in Tehran.
effective_dosage: 100 mg fennel soft capsules, 2 per day.
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention, with a 2-week post-intervention follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fennel, alone or combined with cumin, could reverse obesity-related reproductive dysfunction and improve sperm quality in obese male rats.
results_summary: Fennel treatment (100 and 200 mg/kg) improved sperm quality and reduced testicular apoptosis in obese rats, alongside weight loss and decreased leptin levels. The effects were dose-dependent and comparable to cumin.
population_specificity: Obese male rats (high-fat diet-induced obesity model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and necessity of raising maximum residue levels (MRLs) for deltamethrin in Florence fennel and other crops.
