results_summary: The study concluded that raising MRLs for deltamethrin in Florence fennel would not pose a consumer health risk, as residues at expected levels would not exceed toxicological reference values. Adequate analytical methods were available to enforce compliance with the proposed MRLs.
population_specificity: Not specified (general consumer exposure assessment).
effective_dosage: Not specified (MRL proposal: 0.3 mg/kg for deltamethrin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sweet fennel extract alone and in combination with cisplatin on human cervical cancer cells (HeLa cells) to determine its potential as an effective, low-side-effect therapy.
results_summary: The study found that sweet fennel extract reduced HeLa cell viability, with higher concentrations showing greater effects. Combining 50 μg/ml fennel with cisplatin enhanced cancer growth inhibition, suggesting a potential additive effect.
population_specificity: Human cervical cancer adenocarcinoma cell line (HeLa cells)
interactions: Interaction with cisplatin noted (additive effect at 50 μg/ml fennel)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and tolerability of a combination of curcumin and fennel essential oil (CU-FEO) in relieving symptoms of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: CU-FEO was safe, well-tolerated, and significantly reduced IBS symptoms, including abdominal pain, with a higher percentage of symptom-free patients compared to placebo. Quality of life also improved across all domains.
population_specificity: 121 patients with mild-to-moderate IBS symptoms (IBS-SSS 100-300 and abdominal pain score 30-70 on a VAS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a novel complex chemical solution and subsequent packaging could delay chlorophyll degradation and lignification in fresh-cut water fennel during refrigerated storage.
results_summary: The complex solution treatment reduced chlorophyllase, Mg-dechelatase, and chlorophyll-degrading peroxidase activities, delaying chlorophyll degradation and improving color retention. It also inhibited lignin accumulation by reducing PAL activity, and packaging further preserved chlorophylls and reduced lignification.
population_specificity: Fresh-cut water fennel (plant material, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: 1.16 g/L calcium lactate, 150 mg/L zinc acetate, and 15.29 mg/L salicylic acid (immersion treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the genetic diversity and essential oil composition of Ferula communis L. (giant fennel) populations to inform conservation strategies and potential phytomedical applications.
results_summary: The study identified three distinct chemotypes based on leaf essential oil composition and revealed high genetic diversity among populations, influenced by habitat fragmentation and limited gene flow. No significant correlation was found between genetic markers (RAPD) and chemical profiles, suggesting independent variation.
population_specificity: Endangered Tunisian medicinal plant (Ferula communis L.) populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether drinking fennel tea could suppress subjective appetite in overweight women compared to a placebo.
results_summary: Fennel tea significantly decreased hunger, reduced prospective food consumption, and increased feelings of fullness compared to placebo, though no significant difference in actual food consumption was observed.
population_specificity: Overweight Korean women (mean age 49.7 ± 4.5 years, BMI 24.6 ± 0.6 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of fennel aromatherapy therapy on kidney function using biosignal analysis techniques.
results_summary: The study compared biosignals before and after fennel aromatherapy treatment, suggesting an effect on kidney function, though specific outcomes and statistical significance are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of fennel vaginal cream on vaginal atrophy symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The fennel group showed significant improvements in vaginal pH, maturation vaginal index (MVI), and cell composition compared to the placebo group, with no reported side effects. All women in the fennel group achieved an MVI of 65-100 after 8 weeks, while the control group showed minimal improvement.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 45-65 in Ahvaz, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of fennel in reducing primary dysmenorrhea symptoms and menorrheal duration.
results_summary: The study found that fennel significantly reduced nausea intensity, weakness, and menstrual duration, while improving well-being and stress levels compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 80 female students from Islamic Azad University, Toyserkan.
effective_dosage: 30 mg soft capsule every 4 hours, 3 days before menstruation until the 5th day, continued for 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the renoprotective effects of aqueous extract of Fennel (Foeniculum vulgare) in female rats with experimentally induced polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: The study found that Fennel extract (150 mg/kg b.w.) improved renal function in PCOS rats, as evidenced by reduced blood urea nitrogen levels and favorable histopathological changes in kidney tissues compared to untreated PCOS rats. Lower doses (100 mg/kg b.w.) showed less pronounced effects.
population_specificity: Female rats with experimentally induced PCOS.
effective_dosage: 150 mg/kg b.w. and 100 mg/kg b.w., administered intragastrically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fennel could induce menstrual bleeding and improve continuation rates of DMPA contraception in women experiencing amenorrhea due to DMPA use.
results_summary: Fennel significantly increased menstrual bleeding (73% vs. 19% placebo) and had a higher mean bleeding volume (21 cc) compared to LD-COC (14 cc) and placebo (12 cc). It also improved DMPA continuation rates (73% vs. 31% placebo).
population_specificity: Married women in Iran using DMPA with amenorrhea for 45-140 days.
effective_dosage: Two capsules daily for 21 days (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of topical fennel gel (3%) on reducing hair thickness in women with mild to moderate idiopathic hirsutism.
results_summary: The study found that fennel gel 3% significantly reduced hair thickness after 24 weeks compared to placebo, with minor adverse effects like itching and irritation reported in a few participants. The difference in adverse effects between groups was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 44 women with mild to moderate idiopathic hirsutism (22 in the fennel gel group, 22 in the placebo group).
effective_dosage: 3% fennel gel, applied topically (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze estragole levels in dry fennel preparations and infusions and assess their safety using the Margin of Exposure (MOE) approach.
results_summary: Estragole levels varied widely in dry fennel (0.15-13.3mg/g) and were lower in infusions (0.4-133.4μg/25mL). Safety assessment indicated low risk for adults but higher concern for children unless usage was limited to short-term (1-2 weeks).
population_specificity: Adults and children consuming fennel tea.
effective_dosage: 1-3 cups of fennel tea daily (prepared from 1g dry material).
study_duration: Lifetime for adults, 1-2 weeks for children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the allergen responsible for cross-reactivity between mugwort pollen and fennel in patients with mugwort-celery-spice syndrome.
results_summary: The study identified a 60 kDa allergen in fennel, highly homologous to Api g 5, which showed significant cross-reactivity with mugwort pollen. Inhibition experiments confirmed this allergen's role in the mugwort-celery-spice syndrome.
population_specificity: One index patient with both fennel and mugwort pollen allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of oral fennel drops on pain relief and bleeding severity in individuals with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain relief between the fennel and control groups, but fennel appeared effective in reducing bleeding severity from the first to the fifth day of menstruation. However, most volunteers reported an unpleasant taste.
population_specificity: Sixty college students suffering from primary dysmenorrhea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if fennel essential oil (FEO), as a phytoestrogen source, could protect against cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: FEO did not reduce kidney damage markers (BUN, Cr, KTDS) or body weight changes caused by cisplatin. It also did not alter nitrite levels significantly, showing no nephroprotective effect.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical effect of Foeniculum vulgare (fennel) on primary dysmenorrhoea in virgin girls.
results_summary: The study found that fennel extract was significantly more effective than placebo in relieving menstrual pain, with a statistically significant difference (P < 0.05). Both groups experienced relief, but the fennel group showed superior results.
population_specificity: Sixty virgin girls with primary dysmenorrhoea, of which 50 completed the study.
effective_dosage: 30 mg fennel extract, four times a day for three days starting at the onset of menstruation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the phytotoxic and stimulatory effects of nanosized TiO2 versus bulk TiO2 on fennel seed germination and early growth stages.
results_summary: Nanosized TiO2 at 60 ppm significantly improved germination percentage, shoot dry weight, and germination rate, while bulk TiO2 at 40 ppm reduced shoot biomass by 50%. Low to intermediate nanosized TiO2 concentrations enhanced germination indices like vigor and mean daily germination.
population_specificity: Fennel seeds (medicinal plant model).
effective_dosage: 0, 5, 20, 40, 60, and 80 mg L(-1) nanosized TiO2; 40 ppm bulk TiO2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of fennel essential oil-induced seizures in an epileptic patient and highlight potential risks.
results_summary: The study found that ingestion of fennel essential oil triggered a generalized tonic-clonic seizure in a well-controlled epileptic patient, suggesting it may pose seizure risks for such individuals. The authors recommend labeling and awareness programs to mitigate this risk.
population_specificity: A 38-year-old woman with well-controlled epilepsy.
effective_dosage: Unknown quantity of fennel essential oil in cakes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop biodegradable films from fennel waste and modified phaseolin, assessing their mechanical properties, water vapor permeability, and biodegradability.
results_summary: Transglutaminase-treated fennel-phaseolin films exhibited mechanical properties and water vapor permeability comparable to commercial films (Ecoflex and Mater-Bi) and demonstrated enhanced biodegradation resistance compared to films made with fennel waste alone or unmodified phaseolin.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on film materials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fennel extract versus placebo on reducing the severity of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) symptoms.
results_summary: Fennel extract significantly reduced PMS symptom severity compared to placebo, with post-intervention scores of 64.4±27.5 (fennel) versus 79.1±28.1 (placebo). The effect of fennel was similar to echinophora-platyloba but both were more effective than placebo.
population_specificity: 90 female students with moderate to severe PMS from Shahrekord University of Medical Sciences.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of procymidone in controlling Sclerotinia sclerotiorum on fennel and celery, and to assess residue levels post-treatment.
results_summary: The study found good control of fungal infection in treated plots, with statistically significant differences compared to controls. Residue levels at harvest were 0.1-0.4 mg/kg on fennel and 1.0-3.5 mg/kg on celery.
population_specificity: Fennel and celery crops (field and greenhouse conditions).
effective_dosage: 40 g/hl of active ingredient, applied twice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of fennel tea, particularly in infants with dyspeptic disorders, and address concerns about its potential carcinogenic risk due to estragole content.
results_summary: The study highlights fennel tea's long-standing use and good tolerance in infants, contrasting with recent warnings about estragole's carcinogenicity in animal studies. Experts criticize these warnings due to differences in metabolism between animals and humans, and the protective effects of antioxidants in fennel tea.
population_specificity: Infants and sucklings with dyspeptic disorders, as well as general consumers of fennel tea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical response of idiopathic hirsutism to topical Fennel extract, comparing different concentrations (1% and 2%) against a placebo.
results_summary: The study found that the cream containing 2% Fennel extract was more effective than the 1% formulation, both of which outperformed the placebo. Hair diameter reduction was 7.8% (1%), 18.3% (2%), and -0.5% (placebo).
population_specificity: 38 women with idiopathic hirsutism and normal ovulatory cycles and androgen levels.
effective_dosage: 1% and 2% Fennel extract in topical cream.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of fennel seed oil emulsion in treating infantile colic compared to placebo.
results_summary: Fennel seed oil emulsion significantly reduced colic symptoms in 65% of treated infants, compared to 23.7% in the control group, with no reported side effects. The treatment showed a clinically meaningful improvement (ARR = 41%, NNT = 2).
population_specificity: 125 infants aged 2 to 12 weeks diagnosed with colic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of Fennel (Foeniculum vulgare) versus mefenamic acid for treating primary dysmenorrhea in young women.
results_summary: Fennel effectively relieved menstrual pain, though it was slightly less potent than mefenamic acid on certain days. No major complications were reported, but some participants withdrew due to fennel's odor, and one case reported a mild increase in menstrual flow.
population_specificity: Women aged 15-24 with moderate to severe primary dysmenorrhea.
effective_dosage: 25 drops of 2% Fennel fruit essence every 4 hours orally.
study_duration: Administered over one menstrual cycle (third cycle of the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Fennel Essential Oil (FEO) on uterine contractions induced by oxytocin and prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) and to estimate its LD50 in rats.
results_summary: FEO significantly reduced the intensity of uterine contractions induced by oxytocin and PGE2 at specific doses and also decreased the frequency of PGE2-induced contractions. The LD50 of FEO in female rats was estimated to be 1326 mg/kg, with no obvious damage to vital organs observed.
population_specificity: Female rats
effective_dosage: 25 and 50 µg/ml for oxytocin-induced contractions; 10 and 20 µg/ml for PGE2-induced contractions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the microplastic removal efficiency of polysaccharides derived from fenugreek compared to other plant-based flocculants in water treatment.
results_summary: Fenugreek showed the highest microplastic removal efficiency (∼89%) in groundwater samples, with an optimal concentration of 1 g/L and contact time of 30-60 minutes. The mechanism of removal was identified as bridging, and fenugreek outperformed synthetic flocculants like polyacrylamide.
population_specificity: Water samples from surface, ocean, and groundwater sources.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biological pathways and mechanisms by which fenugreek exerts protective effects against Alzheimer's disease in mice.
results_summary: Fenugreek improved cognitive dysfunction and behavioral deficits in AD mice, modulated inflammatory and oxidative stress-related proteins, and showed a strong correlation with AD pathways in bioinformatics analysis.
population_specificity: Mice model of Alzheimer's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemopreventive potential of methanolic fenugreek seed extract (FSE) in an azoxymethane-induced murine colorectal cancer model, focusing on oxidative stress modulation, biomarker regulation, apoptosis induction, and epithelial integrity maintenance.
results_summary: FSE improved survival rates, reduced serum biomarker levels, restored antioxidant enzyme activity, increased ROS-mediated apoptosis, and restored E-cadherin localization, demonstrating potent chemopreventive effects against colorectal cancer.
population_specificity: Swiss albino mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the structural and optical properties of fenugreek water, its interactions with sugar solutions, anti-diabetes medications, and sunscreen cream, and its potential health and skincare benefits.
results_summary: Fenugreek water showed increased colloidal formation and bioactive compound concentration over time, enhanced UV protection when mixed with sunscreen cream, and improved interaction with anti-diabetes medications by day 3. It also demonstrated antioxidant activity and potential for reducing diabetes levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
interactions: Anti-diabetes medications (Diapride M2 Forte) and sunscreen cream (shadow SPF50 + cream)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fenugreek supplementation could inhibit the growth of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) in rats.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in AAA progression, elastin structure, inflammatory markers, or vascular smooth muscle cell presence between fenugreek-treated groups and controls, indicating no beneficial effects of fenugreek on AAA growth.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with induced AAA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fenugreek seed extract (FSE) exhibits anticancer activity against pancreatic cancer cells and inhibits metastasis.
results_summary: FSE inhibited pancreatic cancer cell proliferation and migration by activating apoptosis-related markers (cleaved caspase-3, Bax) and modulating signaling pathways (MAPK, Akt, MMP-9, vimentin) without significantly affecting normal cells. LC-MS/MS identified active compounds in FSE contributing to these effects.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer cell lines (Panc-1, Miapaca-2, SNU-213, Aspc-1) and normal cells (293T).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of fenugreek (F) and Indian gooseberry (IG), individually and in combination, on SIRT1 protein levels and related antioxidant enzyme activities.
results_summary: The combination of F + IG significantly increased SIRT1 protein levels in serum, heart, liver, and kidneys compared to individual treatments, with IG showing a more pronounced effect than F alone. The combination also produced synergistic and additive effects on antioxidant enzyme activities, including catalase, superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase, and glutathione S-transferase.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro study based on tissue analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of fenugreek seed extract (FCT) to ameliorate testosterone propionate-induced benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in an animal model and its mechanisms in human prostate epithelial cells.
results_summary: FCT reduced prostate weight, DHT levels, and PCNA expression in rats, while also decreasing AR, 5α-reductase 2, Bcl-2, IL-6, TNF-α, and NF-κB expression in vitro and in vivo. It also inhibited BPH-1 cell proliferation dose-dependently.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats and BPH-1 human prostate epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of fenugreek hydrolyzed protein (FHP) on lipid profile in patients with mild-to-moderate hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: FHP significantly improved lipid profile by reducing total cholesterol, LDL-c, and non-HDL-c levels, with no significant change in triglycerides. The supplement was well tolerated, with only one reported gastrointestinal adverse event.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-65 years with mild-to-moderate hypercholesterolemia and low risk for cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fenugreek seed extract (FSE) exhibits neuroprotective potential and enhances the therapeutic outcomes of acellular nerve allograft (ANA) repair in peripheral nerve defects.
results_summary: FSE promoted Schwann cell proliferation and secretion of neurotrophic factors in vitro. In rats with sciatic nerve defects, FSE combined with ANAs enhanced axonal regeneration, improved functional recovery, and reduced neuroinflammation compared to ANAs alone.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with a unilateral 15-mm sciatic nerve defect.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review methodologies for extracting diosgenin from fenugreek seeds and its implications for pharmaceutical research.
results_summary: The study highlights diosgenin's pharmacological properties (anti-inflammatory, anti-cancer, anti-oxidant) and reviews various extraction techniques, emphasizing the need for standardization in quantification methods.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of extraction methods, not a clinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fenugreek polysaccharides (FS60) could enhance the bioavailability of curcumin (Cur) in vivo by improving its water dispersion and absorption.
results_summary: The study found that FS60-curcuminoid aggregates (FC) significantly increased curcumin glucuronide (Cur-O-Glu) levels, with a 51-fold higher Cmax and 19-fold higher AUC0-12h compared to curcuminoid alone. FS60 also promoted Cur ingestion, increased UGT expression, inhibited enterocyte transporters, and modulated gut microbiota to enhance glucuronidation and absorption.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate fenugreek's effectiveness as an adjuvant in managing oral potentially malignant disorders (OPMDs), including leukoplakia, lichen planus, and oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF).
results_summary: Fenugreek showed significant improvement in mouth opening and cheek flexibility for OSMF but no notable differences in leukoplakia or lichen planus compared to standard treatment alone. The study concluded fenugreek could be a cost-effective adjuvant for OPMDs, particularly OSMF.
population_specificity: 21 participants with OPMDs (leukoplakia, lichen planus, or OSMF).
effective_dosage: 2 gm of fenugreek as an adjuvant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bio-organic inputs, including Fenugreek in an intercropping system, on strawberry growth, soil health, and yield efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that Fenugreek intercropping, combined with specific bio-organic treatments (GJ + JV + Azolla), improved soil microbial activity, enzymatic activity, and overall yield compared to conventional fertilizers. T3 (GJ at 100 g/m² + JV at 20% + Azolla at 200 g/plant) showed the most significant positive effects on vegetative growth, flowering duration, and fruit yield.
population_specificity: Strawberry cv. Camarosa in a legume intercropping system (Coriander-Strawberry-Fenugreek).
effective_dosage: Not specified for Fenugreek alone; bio-organic inputs included GJ (100-150 g/m²), JV (10-20%), and Azolla (200-250 g/plant).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the preclinical and clinical antidiabetic properties of fenugreek and its isolated compounds, focusing on underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Preclinical studies showed fenugreek's antidiabetic effects were linked to enhanced GLUT4 translocation, hexokinase activity, and insulin release, while clinical trials demonstrated improved blood glucose levels, insulin resistance, and lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Not specified (preclinical and clinical studies reviewed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether subfractions of fenugreek extract could protect human erythrocytes from oxidative stress and aging induced by H2O2.
results_summary: Four subfractions of fenugreek extract showed protective effects against H2O2-induced hemolysis and oxidative stress, with three subfractions increasing CD47 levels and reducing phosphatidylserine on erythrocyte surfaces. The results suggest fenugreek may safeguard erythrocytes by reducing oxidative stress and preserving structural integrity.
population_specificity: Human erythrocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fenugreek seed dry extract (FDE) on glycemic indices, lipid profile, and prooxidant-antioxidant balance (PAB) in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that FDE significantly reduced serum insulin, HOMA-IR, triglycerides, and PAB compared to baseline, with HDL-C increasing in the FDE group. However, no significant differences were observed between the FDE and placebo groups except for HDL-C.
population_specificity: 54 individuals with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 3 tablets containing 335 mg of FDE daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of microwave and hot water treatments in disinfecting fenugreek seeds and assess the impact of fenugreek sprouts on blood glucose and lipid levels in diabetic rats.
results_summary: Microwave treatment (20 s) was most effective in reducing microbial load while preserving nutritional and antioxidant properties. Fenugreek sprouts (7.5-10% w/w) improved body weight, glucose levels, cholesterol, and triglycerides in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Streptozocin-induced diabetic rats
effective_dosage: 5%, 7.5%, and 10% w/w of fenugreek seeds or sprouts in diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of TrigozimR fenugreek extract on plasma and saliva testosterone levels and subjective effects in aging men with non-optimal testosterone levels.
results_summary: The study found that TrigozimR increased plasma total testosterone and free testosterone index (FTI) compared to baseline but not versus placebo, while saliva testosterone increased significantly versus both baseline and placebo. The 1800 mg dose showed the most pronounced effects, with no reported subjective effects or side effects.
population_specificity: 95 men aged 40-80 years with non-optimal testosterone levels.
effective_dosage: 0 mg (placebo), 600 mg, 1200 mg, and 1800 mg fenugreek extract daily (3 tablets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and metabolic effects of fenugreek seeds versus metformin in women with PCOS, focusing on blood glucose, lipid profiles, and other symptoms.
results_summary: Fenugreek significantly improved lipid profiles (LDL, HDL, TG) compared to metformin and showed benefits for hair loss and hirsutism, though metformin was more effective for reducing biometric indices, fasting blood sugar, and insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Women aged 16-40 years with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardioprotective effects of Trigonelline (a bioactive compound in Fenugreek) in alcohol-intoxicated rats.
results_summary: Trigonelline supplementation restored depleted antioxidant enzymes (SOD, CAT, GPx, GR, GSH), reduced elevated oxidative stress markers (MDA), and lowered cardiac and serum markers (CK-MB, TT, TI, MG, AAT, AST, ALP) in alcohol-intoxicated rats. Histopathological evidence confirmed Trigonelline's protective effect against alcohol-induced cardiac toxicity.
population_specificity: Young Wistar strain albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of fenugreek seed gum (FSG) combined with whey protein isolate (WPI) as a nanoemulsion carrier for pistachio hull extract (PHE) to control oil oxidation and fungal growth in stored pistachio nuts.
results_summary: The study found that pistachio nuts coated with a composite of WPI and FSG containing 100 ppm PHE showed reduced oil oxidation, fungal growth, and better overall acceptance after 8 weeks of storage. The nanoemulsion demonstrated high encapsulation efficiency, antioxidant activity, and antifungal properties.
population_specificity: Fresh pistachio nuts stored at 4°C.
effective_dosage: 100 ppm PHE in the coating solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the potential targets and mechanisms by which stilbenoid compounds in fenugreek seeds improve insulin resistance (IR) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that three stilbenoid compounds (rhaponticin, desoxyrhaponticin, and rhapontigenin) may improve IR through the PI3K/AKT/mTOR signaling pathway, with rhaponticin showing the most promising effects. Molecular docking indicated high binding affinity with PPARG, GAPDH, PI3K, and AKT, suggesting these as potential therapeutic targets.
population_specificity: Zebrafish T2DM model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and hypoglycemic effects of fenugreek seeds (FS) when incorporated into a chickpea pulao and its impact on postprandial blood glucose levels in type 2 diabetic individuals.
results_summary: Fenugreek seeds demonstrated significant antioxidant and hypoglycemic activity, reducing postprandial hyperglycemia by approximately 15% daily compared to the control recipe. The study found statistically significant results (p = .000) for both raw and boiled extracts in inhibiting α-amylase and α-glucosidase.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic individuals (12 participants).
effective_dosage: Concentrations tested: 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9% (best-chosen concentration used for formulation, exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: 3 weeks with a one-week wash-over period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of fenugreek leaf oil on the expression of Ki-67 in rat mucosal ulcers to determine its potential to accelerate wound healing.
results_summary: The study found that fenugreek leaf oil significantly increased Ki-67 expression in ulcer-induced rats compared to controls, indicating accelerated healing. The effect was more pronounced on the 3rd day, suggesting fenugreek's potential to enhance early-stage wound repair.
population_specificity: Male Wistar albino rats (350-450 gm weight) with surgically induced mucosal ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Fenfuro®'s ability to inhibit glycation and amyloid formation in proteins linked to diabetic complications.
results_summary: Fenfuro® (0.25% w/v) reduced glycation by over 50% and amyloid formation by 14-36% in three proteins. It also partially prevented molecular weight changes and restored normal protein size distribution.
population_specificity: In vitro study (proteins: alpha-synuclein, Serum albumin, Lysozyme)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of Fenfuro® (a fenugreek seed formulation) in controlling glycemic indices in individuals on antidiabetic therapy.
results_summary: After 12 weeks, Fenfuro® significantly reduced fasting and postprandial glucose levels by 38% and 44%, respectively, and glycated hemoglobin by 34.7%, with no adverse effects on safety parameters.
population_specificity: 81 individuals (42 in treatment, 39 in placebo) aged 18-65 on Metformin or Metformin with sulphonylurea therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of zirconium MOF-based fenugreek composite beads (FG/Zr-AIPA) for removing heavy metals (Cr(VI), Pb(II), and Fe(III) from aqueous solutions.
results_summary: The FG/Zr-AIPA composite beads demonstrated high adsorption capacities (344.43, 270.02, and 223.21 mg g−1 for Cr(VI), Pb(II), and Fe(III), respectively) through monolayer chemisorption, with good reusability and spontaneous, endothermic interactions.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on aqueous solutions).
effective_dosage: Not specified (composite beads used in adsorption experiments).
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on adsorption kinetics and thermodynamics).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms and gene expression profiles underlying diosgenin accumulation in fenugreek plants treated with methyl jasmonate to enhance diosgenin biosynthesis.
results_summary: The study found that methyl jasmonate treatment upregulated key genes (SQS, SEP, CAS) involved in diosgenin biosynthesis, with peak expression at 72 hours, and identified additional genes (Δ24, SMT1) directing metabolic flux toward diosgenin production. Bioinformatics and real-time PCR validation confirmed these findings, offering insights for improving diosgenin yield.
population_specificity: Fenugreek plants treated with methyl jasmonate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ascaroside (ascr)#18 treatment could effectively control enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) growth on fenugreek sprouts.
results_summary: Treatment with ascr#18 significantly reduced EHEC populations on fenugreek sprouts, with 1 mM and 1 μM doses lowering bacterial counts by 3.31 and 1.56 log CFU/g, respectively, compared to controls. Sprout seed type and sprouting time also influenced EHEC growth, but the strain type did not.
population_specificity: Commercial fenugreek seeds and sprouts contaminated with EHEC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify stable reference genes for accurate gene expression analysis in fenugreek under various stress conditions and elicitor treatments.
results_summary: The study identified EEF-1α, GAPDH, and β-tubulin as the most stable reference genes for gene expression analysis in fenugreek under multiple stress conditions. The findings highlighted the importance of selecting appropriate reference genes to ensure accurate results in real-time PCR studies.
population_specificity: Fenugreek plants subjected to salinity, temperature stresses, and elicitor treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a herbal blend (including fenugreek) on broiler chickens' growth performance, nutrient digestibility, and blood metabolites.
results_summary: The study found that a 1% phytogenic mixture (including fenugreek) significantly improved live weight, carcass weight, crude protein and fat digestibility, and lipid profile in broilers. A 3% mixture enhanced calcium and phosphorus digestibility.
population_specificity: Broiler chickens (Cobb 500)
effective_dosage: 1%, 2%, and 3% of diet supplemented with the herbal blend (coriander, garlic, fenugreek)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foliar applications of zinc and boron could mitigate salinity stress and improve fenugreek growth and physiology.
results_summary: Salinity stress significantly reduced fenugreek growth metrics, but foliar applications of zinc (100 ppm) and boron (2 ppm) improved shoot and root length, fresh and dry weights, chlorophyll content, and nutrient uptake while reducing sodium ion content.
population_specificity: Fenugreek plants under salinity stress (0 and 120 mM NaCl).
effective_dosage: Zinc (0, 50, 100 ppm) and boron (0, 2 ppm) applied as foliar spray.
study_duration: 35 days of salt treatment followed by foliar application (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore diosgenin's potential in preventing and treating diabetes by examining its extraction, pharmacological properties, and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that diosgenin, derived from fenugreek, may help prevent diabetes by modulating cellular pathways such as Akt, PKC/GLUT4, PPAR, and inhibiting enzymes like α-amylase and α-glucosidase. It also suggests diosgenin could influence lipid metabolism and apoptosis-related proteins.
population_specificity: Not specified (general diabetic mechanisms discussed, no specific human or animal population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fenugreek seed extracts (FSEs) on the oxidation and structural changes of duck myofibrillar protein (MP) in a Fenton oxidation system.
results_summary: FSE demonstrated significant antioxidant properties, reducing hydroxyl radical scavenging by 58.79%, decreasing carbonyl formation and sulfhydryl loss in MP, and improving protein solubility and structural integrity. It also altered secondary protein structures and restored particle size and zeta potential to baseline levels.
population_specificity: Duck myofibrillar protein (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how melatonin concentrations, cold plasma treatment, and exposure durations affect fenugreek's physiological and biochemical attributes, particularly diosgenin levels, under salinity stress.
results_summary: The study found that combining 60 ppm melatonin with 3000 V cold plasma for 2 min enhanced fenugreek's stress tolerance by improving redox homeostasis, reducing pigment destruction, and increasing diosgenin content and related gene expression. The treatments also boosted abscisic acid, auxin, and endogenous melatonin levels.
population_specificity: Fenugreek plants under salinity stress.
effective_dosage: 30 and 60 ppm melatonin; cold plasma at 3000 and 4000 V for 1, 2, and 4 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the chemical composition of fenugreek seeds, particularly their antioxidant properties and α-amylase inhibition activities, to assess their potential benefits for diabetes prevention.
results_summary: The methanolic extract of fenugreek seeds showed high levels of phenolics and flavonoids, strong antioxidant capacity across multiple assays, and significant α-amylase inhibition activity, suggesting potential benefits for diabetes management.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively evaluate the clinical utility of garlic by analyzing systematic reviews on its effects across various health conditions.
results_summary: Garlic was found to reduce blood pressure in hypertensive patients but not in normotensive subjects. Evidence on lipid parameters, cancer risk reduction, antiglycemic effects, and cardiovascular outcomes was inconclusive or insufficient.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients, normotensive subjects, and general populations in various health contexts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare vaginal candidal colony counts in women taking garlic tablets versus placebo to assess its potential impact on asymptomatic Candida colonization.
results_summary: The study found that 37% of asymptomatic women with prior VVC episodes were colonized with Candida, but the abstract does not report specific results comparing garlic tablets to placebo in reducing colonization.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic women aged 18-50 with at least one self-reported VVC episode in the previous 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of garlic (dried and non-powdered preparations) on peripheral arterial occlusive disease, focusing on objective and subjective measures of atherosclerosis progression.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in pain-free walking distance or other measured outcomes between the garlic and placebo groups. No severe side effects were reported, though a noticeable garlic smell was more common in the garlic group.
population_specificity: Men and women aged 40 to 75 with lower limb atherosclerosis.
